block.p: Sonya Marie Sobieski and Robert Dalgleish Davenport were married yesterday by Mayor Gerard Ryan of Maplewood, N.J., at the Maplewood Municipal Building. Eleanor Applewhite Terry, an Episcopal lay minister and a friend of the bride, took part in the ceremony.

The bride, 30, is the literary manager of Playwrights Horizons, an Off Broadway theater in Manhattan. ''The Joy Of,'' which she wrote, won the best play award in the 1997 New York International Fringe Festival, which focuses on experimental theater.

Sonya Marie Sobieski and Robert Dalgleish Davenport were married yesterday by Mayor Gerard Ryan of Maplewood, N.J., at the Maplewood Municipal Building. Eleanor Applewhite Terry, an Episcopal lay minister and a friend of the bride, took part in the ceremony.

The bride, 30, is the literary manager of Playwrights Horizons, an Off Broadway theater in Manhattan. ''The Joy Of,'' which she wrote, won the best play award in the 1997 New York International Fringe Festival, which focuses on experimental theater.
The bridegroom, 29, is a director, a Drama League directing fellow and a member of the Lincoln Center Directors Lab.

Ms. Sobieski, 30, will keep her name. She graduated magna cum laude from Smith College and is a daughter of Nancy and Alexander Sobieski of Maplewood, N.J. Her mother is a retired staff manager in cost analysis at AT&T in New York. Her father, a retired manufacturing manager for Procter & Gamble, worked in its Norfolk, Va., office.

Mr. Davenport graduated cum laude from Yale University. His mother, Martha Davenport of Mercer Island, Wash., is a professor of English at Olympic College in Bremerton, Wash. His father, Franklyn J. Davenport of Bellevue, Wash., is a retired Boeing aerospace engineer.
